1424846347417575434.text: But it is not too late to prevent the worst impacts. Every bit of warming means more intense heat, more storms, and more flooding. For example, the report estimates extreme rain will intensify by 7% for each 1°C warming.

1424846284721168397.text: Even if we stopped all CO2 emissions today, sea level rise would continue for centuries, reshaping our coastlines and inundating cities and island nations.

1424846220766425091.text: Burning fossil fuels led to more widespread and severe wildfires, tropical storms, droughts, and coastal flooding. Heatwaves have approximately doubled in frequency since the 1980s.

1424846156224466948.text: Humans have caused almost all of the current warming, about 1.07°C out of 1.09°C. Since the last IPCC Assessment Report, scientific evidence of the link between global warming and current extreme weather events has grown.

1424845998325739523.text: This report is the clearest description of how dire the climate emergency has become, and the clearest call to action we’ve ever received on the greatest existential crisis of our time. In sum:

❌ FBI & DOJ officials can’t identify & locate sex trafficking victims & perpetrators as well.  

❌ Sex workers are more unsafe.

❌ Is anyone actually safer because of FOSTA-SESTA? No.

✅ Is it time to repeal this law? Yes. 8/8

1410650951778803717.text:
Issue #3: The financial aspect is harder to track.

Following laundered 💵 through shell companies based in corporate secrecy jurisdictions is significantly more difficult than following laundered money through U.S.-based financial institutions that are subject to U.S. laws. 7/

1410650550090227716.text:
Issue #2: It’s become *harder* to find evidence of sex trafficking.

The commercial market has moved overseas & investigators are less familiar with new platforms - many of which refuse to voluntarily respond to legal inquiries. Mutual assistance can take months, if not years. 6/

1410650424072454152.text:
Issue #1: Criminal restitution has not been sought even once under FOSTA-SESTA.

It's easier for prosecutors to use racketeering & money laundering charges to prosecute sex trafficking. For a law passed specifically to help prosecutors, FOSTA-SESTA has gotten very little use. 5/

1410650312667549700.text: After FOSTA-SESTA was enacted, these sites (and the tools that came with them) shuttered overnight. The law was meant to make it easier to prosecute sex trafficking. But according to the government's own study, it’s only made things worse for sex workers. 4/

1410650081762680838.text: Before FOSTA-SESTA, many sex workers used online platforms to screen clients. Negotiations could happen virtually, instead of on the street. Some sites even provided vetting tools, like blacklists of dangerous clients. All of this meant that working online was safer. 3/

1410649916205060101.text: In 2018, against the advice of multiple sex worker coalitions & many advocates, Congress passed FOSTA-SESTA. The bill made websites legally liable for content that helps "facilitate prostitution." But there was no distinction made for consensual sex work. 2/

1410649799548878848.text:
In June, the GAO released a report on sex trafficking. The findings were as we expected: there's no evidence that FOSTA/SESTA has made it easier to find & prosecute incidents of sex trafficking. If anything, it's made it  impossible.

Let's rewind ⬇️ 1/
https://t.co/TPzJAqf6hm
